reviews.text: Why two stars? This is truly an important and fascinating place to visit.  I would even say a must visit if in Jerusalen. However, the English guided tour we had was very poor as far as knowledge of the sites and history as well as in terms of language proficiency.

All of my life I have heard stories from the Bible and somehow thought all of those places would take days or weeks to walk to. It is interesting how close the Mount of Olives,  Gethsemane, Galgotha and other places are. My wife and I felt completely safe walking to and around the Old City as well as strolling around Jerusalem.

This place is incredible! If you love Biblical history and want to walk through time, this is the place to go! Asher was an awesome guide. His background in archeology and great knowledge of the Bible, really made it a memorable event!

Fascinating excavation of the ancient city of Jerusalem. We took the three hour guided tour with tour guide Yossi. Although it is possible to explore the area on your own, the perspective of a knowledgeable tour guide is invaluable. Although we elected to take the dry route through the water tunnels, two members of our group went through the water. If you do this you must bring good sneakers or boots and remember that at the beginning the water is 70cm deep.
Fascinating place! Going into Hezekiah tunnel is a an awesome historical experience. I highly recommend to visit it.

Just two small rooms,one for men and the other for women! A man asking for money which goes for charity...he gave me a candle and wrote my name on a piece of paper and putt it inside the tomb for good luck...
the 17th Prophet David PBUH, part of pilgrim.  Rich of Culture such as building and atmosphere
Amazing to be able just to walk in and oray at such a significant pkace. Apparently I'm aroind 106 generations from him!
Great spiritual location to pray.

King David's Tomb is a synagouge (Jewish Place of Prayer) located on Mt. Zion next to Diaspora Yeshiva. It is located above the entrance to the burial cave complex of King David and it leads to his tomb.
 The entrance to the tomb itself is sealed by a monument stone, but it is open to the public. Keep in mind thay while any private individual may pray there GROUP  services of other faiths are prohibited by law.
  Please be respectful of the holiness of this place and cover your head at all times.
This is the house of Caiaphas. An amazing historical place to see. You really get a vivid idea of the night Jesus had in front of the High Priest before  standing before Pilot.

The Church of the cockroach is more than wonderful because you will discover in the cellar how they took the Lord Jesus Christ to this place and go down with the rope and leave him for days without food or eating until they took him to trial at Pilate. And this is what we did not know about him. In this place, I advise you to visit this church because it deserves to discover the truth of the place, and the church is more than wonderful.

This church is the place of Caiaphas the High Priest in the New Testament. He played a major role in the arrest and torture of Jesus, and while the church is impressive...even more staggering is the 3 levels of prison cellars underneath where they tortured Jesus. It is dark, somber and very thought provoking. 

I suggest reading Psalm 88 while you are here to get a glimpse of what Jesus felt while he was in this place.

Place where Jesus spent his last night before being cruxified. Spending some time in the lowest dungeon of the high priest Caiaphas' palace is a sombering thought while meditating on Psalm 88. I actually sat down in the small niche under the stairs, experiencing the dampness and cold...

Amazing experience. You see the steps Jesus took after his arrest. You see the spot where Peter denied Christ in the courtyard. You see the cell where he was held under the house of Caiphas. Really moving. Do not miss!

Why two stars? This is truly an important and fascinating place to visit.  I would even say a must visit if in Jerusalen. However, the English guided tour we had was very poor as far as knowledge of the sites and history as well as in terms of language proficiency.

All of my life I have heard stories from the Bible and somehow thought all of those places would take days or weeks to walk to. It is interesting how close the Mount of Olives,  Gethsemane, Galgotha and other places are. My wife and I felt completely safe walking to and around the Old City as well as strolling around Jerusalem.

This place is incredible! If you love Biblical history and want to walk through time, this is the place to go! Asher was an awesome guide. His background in archeology and great knowledge of the Bible, really made it a memorable event!

Fascinating excavation of the ancient city of Jerusalem. We took the three hour guided tour with tour guide Yossi. Although it is possible to explore the area on your own, the perspective of a knowledgeable tour guide is invaluable. Although we elected to take the dry route through the water tunnels, two members of our group went through the water. If you do this you must bring good sneakers or boots and remember that at the beginning the water is 70cm deep.
Fascinating place! Going into Hezekiah tunnel is a an awesome historical experience. I highly recommend to visit it.
Best  experience.   Peace and spiritual  uplift ment.  Every Muslim must visit even if it's once in a lifetime

Mosque located within the same plaza as the dome of the rock. It is a worship place so you must be respectful all the time. The place can also be accessed through the access point at the Dung gate. No entrance fee, however check the entrance times that are usually two, one in the morning and one in the afternoon. Closed on  Fridays.
I am very lucky to visit our third most sacred place on this planet. May Allah grant it freedom from Israeli occupation.

Awesome.. Wonderful place.. I love it.. I hope be there.. Every second.. Every minute.. Every hour.. Every day.. All Muslims from all countries can found here.. Different languages.. Different skins.. Different countries.. Different ages.. But same aim.. Pray for Allah.. Supplicate to Allah for help the Muslims everywhere.. To save them also.. And they Supplicate for AlAqsa Masjid to be free.. And get the factor.. And save it.... Here you can feel that your spirit touched the sky from happiness.. You will forget all your problems here.. My feelings can't shown by words.. You can go there and feel what's I feel.. I hope to be there this year 
. And every year.. I will be happy there...أولى القبلتين.. ثالث المسجدين.. اللهم احفظه و حرره من دنس اليهود..
An amazing experience! I would highly recommend to visit
I saw much of these sites in November. They need better markings. There are so many and some of them are not identified very well, but it is so massive it is astounding! It was a great experience.
A really nice viewpoint to the Temple Mount and the old town of Jerusalem. If it's possible come early in the morning otherwise it is to crowdedly.

Head into the section of the Jewish cemetery below a panoramic viewpoint, via a staircase, to find this underground set of ancient rock-cut tombs. Jewish tradition holds that they house the graves of the prophets Haggai, Zachariah and Malachi, who lived in the 5th and 6th centuries BCE. Modern archaeologists tend to dispute this, however, dating the tombs to later centuries. The friendly caretaker provides candles to help light the way on a short circular route.
Very interesting.
mount of olives (holy land)
Not many people know but the crypt where everyone walks past is where Princess Alice (Prince Philip's mum) is buried according to her wish to be near her auntie the Grand Duchess.
A well built Russian Orthodox Church. Mainly having historical significance in 1800s. Walking up the church is tiresome. Not recommended if you are  elderly with a leg problem.
Beautiful, solemn church
Not to be missed if you are a Christian travelling in the Holy Land. Contains the relics of the New Martyr Elizabeth
This church is so striking and beautiful. I had to come close and see it. Wanted to go inside but was closed.
do not miss it.  Especially if you are there on a Sunday and are able to attend Divine Liturgy in the morning.

Once-in-a-lifetime opportunity The temple of the lady is so powerful I would ask all the rathkeale travellers to visit the site  Foxy Eileen you have to go  I have played for everybody May God bless you  from Jimmy Lou

Church under the administration of Greek and Armenian Church. The main space is below ground level, so you have to descend the long, wide stairs from 12th century.  Current church was build in Gothic style in 14th century, but Romanesque portal and stairs are from the Crusaders era, the rock tomb is from 5th century. According to tradition it is the tomb of the Virgin Mary. A very mystical place.

We visited our Holy Land, The State of Israel, and were fortunate to visit the Tomb of the Virgin, where we prayed for world peace!

Highly recommend

The Tomb of the Virgin Mary is situated near the Church of All Nations and the Garden of Gethsemane. Visiting the tomb is a memorable experience: Visitors must go deep underground, down a staircase that was carved in the rock during the twelfth century. Immediately surrounding is a sparkling array of iconography, hanging from the ceiling and decorating the cave walls. Medieval art, including a painting of the Madonna and Child, adorn this sanctuary.
The crypt is sheltered within a barrier, so that a visitor must bend forward in order to enter. This forces people to bow and thereby demonstrate their respect for the sanctity of the site. The tomb has been dated as early as the first century. A church was built above the tomb during the same period that Constantine built the Church of the Holy Sepulchre, where some Catholics believe the tomb of Jesus is located. Most Christians believe that Mary was resurrected after her death.

Such a beautiful garden! Serene and full of information about Jesus tomb! Moving, inspiring, and definitely a spiritual connection, if you believe,  to what may be Jesus Tomb! A must see. Volunteers are on site to explain it all. You will be greeted with a warm and friendly smile!

Incredible. Loved our guide that gave us information and background on the tomb. Great spot that had areas for either a private moment of reflection or time with a group (we took communion). An experience I will never forget! The bathrooms are clean and the gift shop provides some memorable things to purchase.

The garden tomb was overall was a great experience.  Our tour guide was Irish, I cannot remember his name but he was fantastic...ask for him!

As with most sights we can’t be exactly sure this was the actual place.  However it’s great to get an idea of what it would of been like.  Jesus was raise fr this earth anyway...so it really doesn’t matter!

Garden Tomb- probably one of the best places to have a quite time in prayer and worship in Jerusalem city. This place brings the events alive, you will have full understanding of Jesus crucifixion, death and resurrection. Definitely a place of blessing for all nations.

Beautiful, serene place to have communion, pray and meditate on Christ Jesus words. It is the place where the actual tomb is. I saw photos from the early excavation more than 40 years ago when the round stone was actually still there. Obviously the tomb is empty because the Holy Spirit resurrected Jesus on the 3rd day and he is alive and seated on the right hand of the Father till his return on Mount Olives.
Jewish settlement in the heart of Jerusalem. Don't go.
ויה דולרוזה העיר העתיקה
!!!!המקום הכי נוח בירושלים

מקום קדוש ועתיק.
 כל
 הנכנס לקבר אז חייב לזכור מלפני ללכת ליטול ידים.
מה הקשר

It's nice seeing people from different religions and confessions praying together the One God in one place. In contrast to the Holy city of Jerusalem where finding a place to meditate is so hard, the Western Wall allows the believer to pass a quiet time of reflection and prayer

The energy, architecture, and peacefulness that was felt when I visited the Western Wall was absolutely amazing. There were a lot of people who visited, but it didn't seem to get overly crowded, which was nice.
Beautiful and Holy place. I am very thankful to the Jewish people for sharing this and allowing the world to share in what is most sacred to them.

As a person who doesn't pray whatsoever, nor am I religious in any other way, I still enjoyed the peacefulness and energy of the place. If not for religious reasons, go for the beautiful structures and vibes of Jerusalem

No word can describe my feeling when see this magnificent wall. For those who like me who are not believing in the religion, this is a very worthy place to visit and feel the culture with the Jewish people.

It's nice seeing people from different religions and confessions praying together the One God in one place. In contrast to the Holy city of Jerusalem where finding a place to meditate is so hard, the Western Wall allows the believer to pass a quiet time of reflection and prayer

The energy, architecture, and peacefulness that was felt when I visited the Western Wall was absolutely amazing. There were a lot of people who visited, but it didn't seem to get overly crowded, which was nice.
Beautiful and Holy place. I am very thankful to the Jewish people for sharing this and allowing the world to share in what is most sacred to them.

As a person who doesn't pray whatsoever, nor am I religious in any other way, I still enjoyed the peacefulness and energy of the place. If not for religious reasons, go for the beautiful structures and vibes of Jerusalem

No word can describe my feeling when see this magnificent wall. For those who like me who are not believing in the religion, this is a very worthy place to visit and feel the culture with the Jewish people.
It's very pleasant place to be. The square gives you a well needed breathing space after a walk in the old City.  It's very beautiful in the night.
I lived near here highly recommended has a nice interior design of the synague.
This review is for the pretty golden menorah outside of the synagogue. We didn't go in due to Sabbath

The square in front of this historied building is a good place to hang out after dark and meet all sorts of friendly people and have lively conversations. There we met a kind man who spoke good English and invited us to attend the coming day's gathering with a famous orthodox Rabbi, arguing, that "even if you're not a Jew or a believer, come, there will be lots of food!"
Most beautiful cultural synagogue

This is a must see on your visit to Jerusalem!! they show a movie that will take back to a time of 2,000 years ago when the bies hamikdash stood and the Roman's were coming to invade Jerusalem and destroy the bies hamikdash the movie will capture your feelings as you watch the stories of the navi come to life, it's a really amazing movie if you know the navi and the history of the churban bies hamikdash it will leave you feeling like crying for the geulah for moshiach to come already and bring us back to eretz yisroel and you will really feel what we are missing without the bies hamikdash and the korbonos and the shichinah. Daven to hashem that he should bring the final redemption already 🙏

Interesting second temple period ruin, with well-preserved artifacts and a rather decent museum, is a great follow-up to the Tower of David museum and Davidson Archaeological Center. There is a small museum, but the highlight is a short film narrated by a member of priestly family that owned the house. The house itself was destroyed in 70 AD, during the aftermath of the Roman Siege of Jerusalem. There may be an admission fee, but I cannot remember if there is. The site is not usually crowded, and they have both Hebrew and English displays.

An exceptionally clear evidence to the destruction of JM in the 2nd temple Era, by the Roman empire army. Moreover, it has evidence of something even more compelling: the evidence found, shows the division in the population even before the Romans destroyed the city.
A very sad story, but it's possible to take more from it: to learn from the past and the disagreements we have with one another, and not let them destroy us as moral people.
Great place to learn the jewish history of the macabees.
Play house is beautiful
Such a wonderful place. Helpful staff. Great shop. So.much to c and learn. Very professional.

We had a really interesting and enjoyable time, as the 2 of us were the only ones in our group.  I have to say, it makes it a lot more fun and informative to get up close to everything and be able to take your time and look closely and thoroughly without guilt, plus no chatter around.  We loved the two videos at the end!

Unfortunately there was no personal german guide provided. The guide was a loud audio guide in the rooms. The text was read by some students / kids. It was hard to understand. In each room the exhibition elements are explained in a messed up way. Additionally you wont have enough time i. Each of the rooms to have a detailed look on the exhibition elements because they ocfer just a limited time.
Very interesting lore of the temple and preparations to have another in the future

One of my favorite places to come to! You will really understand the process of the temple and the temple sacrifices, while having a hope for a future of.having the temple restored! I sincerely enjoy what this place is doing!

I loved coming to this place! ❤
The owner is so nice and polite, that it is always a pleasure talking to him. His paintings, litographies, jewelry and so many pieces of art are so exquisite. I bought him a necklace and a canvas; I got a very good price. 😁

The Museum of Psalms now has a store down two levels from the original Museum of Psalms.   It had only been open 4 months when we came upon it.  

This particular store was our favorite of all the stores in the Old City. Mordecai has carefully selected artists for whom he would like to showcase their art and give the public availability to purchase their work.  All the artwork he has chosen is beautiful, reasonably priced, and unlike anything we had seen before.  The artists he has chosen are extremely talented.  The artists we spoke to were humble about their own work and promoted the work of others in the gallery.  We found this to be refreshing and rare. Needless to say we felt quite fortunate to have come upon this shop during our visit to Jerusalem.  

The Museum of the Psalms was one of only two stores in the Old City that we felt the peace to wander, browse, and ask questions without any pressure.   There was great respect given to the customers.   All from our tour group who found the store made note of this difference and spoke of it being their favorite store as well. 

We did not have the opportunity to visit the upstairs Museum Of The Psalms that all others are mentioning here but we did peek in the windows and saw the beauty that all have mentioned.  Hopefully we can return to Jerusalem one day and have the privilege of getting to see and hear about the displayed work.  

We found Mordecai and two of the artist’s he showcases in his store (one of whom was Azriel Gess) to be honorable men. It was a pleasure to have met them as well as have their work in our home and in our friend’s homes in the states.   

Many friends purchased artwork from this store to take home and a couple of us ordered artwork (prints & paintings) that would be shipped later to us in the states. The ordered artwork arrived for each of us in perfect condition and was shipped for free. 

If you visit the Old City we encourage you to visit both The Museum of The Psalms Store which is in the lower level of the Jewish Quarter and the upstairs Museum of The Psalms.
Very beautiful small museum with a nice guide
Didn't spend much time
I love this museum!!  A  spiritual experience.  The feeling is amazing.  The art is beautiful!

You can only visit certain days and between 15:00 and 15:30, for free. The mass is beautiful, with chanting in Armenian and in general a very spiritual and "back-in-time" feeling. An interesting glimpse in the only occupant of Jerusalem that has never gotten into trouble with anybody else!
A very beautiful Armenian cathedral. The first in history. Open only between 15:00 and 15:30, and I recommend to visit it on time

This hidden gem is too-often overlooked by pilgrim groups and tourists. The St James Cathedral is beautiful, and especially worth visiting for monastic prayers or services. And the Armenian Christians were incredibly welcoming to us, explaining their liturgy to us as we went. We would definitely go back.
It was believe that this was the place where James were buried. It was known also that Armenians who built this church was one of the few first church they built.
Very nice place and very unique

לא המקום.
עם ישראל חי

In das armenische Viertel verlieren sich nicht ganz so viele Touristen. Dabei ist das Viertel mit seinen Museen und seinen Kirchen genau so interessant wie der Rest des alten Jerusalem. Ich empfehle den Besuch dieses Teils der Stadt und man sollte sich auch dafür etwas Zeit nehmen. Ihr werdet es nicht bereuen.

The Lutheran Church of the Redeemer is the second Protestant church in Jerusalem (the first being Christ Church near Jaffa Gate). It is a property of the Evangelical Jerusalem Foundation, one of the three foundations of the Evangelical Church in Germany  in the Holy Land. Inside the bell tower of the Church of the Redeemer, a circular staircase of 178 steps offers panoramic views of Jerusalem from 40 metres up. It is the home to congregations that worship in Arabic, German, Danish and English.

What a beautiful church, and what a beautiful place. Fom the hustle and bustle you step into the peace. Climb the tower, for a spectacular view over the old city, and descend to excavations until the 1st century BC, from the time of Herod the Great. Enjoy coffee in the cloister and courtyard. What a pearl, this place! Highly recommended!
Fantastic church. This was unexpected, you are able to climb the bell tower and from the top you have great all round views of East and West Jerusalem. Well worth the effort climbing the stairs!
Looking forward to visiting this majestic Lutheran Church. In my next visit. To Jerusalem.
An unparalleled view of the city from climbing the tower. Be sure to also visit the vault. Very interesting.

The Church of St. John the Baptist is one of the oldest churches in Jerusalem, with roots dating back to the mid 5th century. Historically, it has been a Mosque as well as a hospice during the Crusader period. However, presently it is a Greek Orthodox church. 

The exterior of the building is being restored at present, meaning it can't be accessed at Muristan. However, if you walk back to Christian Quarter Road, you'll find a small alleyway leading to the courtyard where the church can be entered and visited. You will notice a small sign which states that the church remains open from 9am to 5pm daily but closed on Sundays. 

Inside you will find darkly lit rooms decorated in early Christian and Greek Orthodox manner. Attractive chandeliers hang from a ceiling and there are nicely painted images to see. Heavily gilded iconostasis and entire walls lined with beautiful iconic images can be seen. The interior is small and can be conveniently enjoyed in 5-10 minutes if you are short on time. 

Overall, The Church of St. John the Baptist is an interesting ancient church that many seem to skip or not know about. We really enjoyed finding and visiting while sightseeing in the Christian Quarter and would gladly return if we were to visit the city again.
January 9 Jesus of Nazareth love you go live hope  in prominent live faith program problem in Jesus come
Currently restoration. Hard to locate but walk along the marketplace till see a small entrance.

Nice place To Visit but  closed
Most
Of the times nice small garthen
Wow

The Monastery of the Flagellation is an important attraction along the Via Dolorosa in the Muslim Quarter of Jerusalem. This is the location where is is believed that Jesus was flogged by the Roman soldiers. Opening hours are from 9-1pm and 4-6pm daily. 

Here you can find a pleasant but small courtyard flanked by two chapels. The Chapel of the Condemnation is a 20th century chapel built upon the grounds of medieval period chapel. The interior is that of a small seating area with nice stained glass windows. 

Across the courtyard is a second Chapel of the Flagellation, which was originally built during the Crusader period and then restored by Italian architect Antonio Barluzzi in 1929. Here you can see a nice altar with an image of Christ being led beside the cross. 

Between the two chapels is a small archaeological museum called Terra Sancta Museum. We didn't have time to visit but this might be of interest to some. They have a website online if you want to know more about what can be experienced here. 

Overall, we found the Monastery of Flagellation to be a nice addition to the various attractions along Via Dolorosa. Its worth a visit if you plan to trace the steps of Jesus and visit the 14 stations along this street.
awesome
Breath taken
Impressive chapel in a building designed by the famous Antonio Barluzzi. Stained glass windows tell the story of this Second Station along the Via Dolorosa.
beautiful building
Descending into the bowels of the earth has its own mystique. Seeing the evidence for building Temple period Jerusalem is fascinating. Witnessing the ancient engineering skill is fascinating.
An amazing sight to behold. A nice area that is not as crowded as other places in Jerusalem but you definitely want to see it.
Very dangerous environment. Doesn't worth the risk of running into a mad Arab person (and there are a lot there). Recommend to avoid.
Stunning to see how they lived here two millennia ago.. and to be able to see the actual cave of the scrolls is amazing
Always great place to visit. 18 shekels for adults. Nice walk within the cave under the old city.
Best  experience.   Peace and spiritual  uplift ment.  Every Muslim must visit even if it's once in a lifetime

Mosque located within the same plaza as the dome of the rock. It is a worship place so you must be respectful all the time. The place can also be accessed through the access point at the Dung gate. No entrance fee, however check the entrance times that are usually two, one in the morning and one in the afternoon. Closed on  Fridays.
I am very lucky to visit our third most sacred place on this planet. May Allah grant it freedom from Israeli occupation.

Awesome.. Wonderful place.. I love it.. I hope be there.. Every second.. Every minute.. Every hour.. Every day.. All Muslims from all countries can found here.. Different languages.. Different skins.. Different countries.. Different ages.. But same aim.. Pray for Allah.. Supplicate to Allah for help the Muslims everywhere.. To save them also.. And they Supplicate for AlAqsa Masjid to be free.. And get the factor.. And save it.... Here you can feel that your spirit touched the sky from happiness.. You will forget all your problems here.. My feelings can't shown by words.. You can go there and feel what's I feel.. I hope to be there this year 
. And every year.. I will be happy there...أولى القبلتين.. ثالث المسجدين.. اللهم احفظه و حرره من دنس اليهود..
An amazing experience! I would highly recommend to visit

My Egyptian friend who is local to Cairo told me to check this place out. Well worth the time! Entrance fee for a student at the time was 50£, and they do have a bag check. The additional charge for take photos is also worth doing, AND they do rigorously check to make you paid the photo fee. 

The museum takes about 1-2 hours, and is full of beautiful rugs, coins, door ways and furniture. Most information is in arabic, so its easy to justify the visit for the non-reader museum types. I could hardly understand anything, but still fully enjoyed the look.

For everyone who interested in history, architecture or art, this place is your gem. It has almost everything about the Islamic art. Also it's very organized according to every Islamic era which make it easy to get the history behind it.

The place is amazing. It provides a great experience for Muslim history in different aspects of life. The museum is very clean and neat. The staff is very friendly, there is a small parking slot especially for tourists and there is also a general parking place close to the museum.

This is my favourite museum in Cairo. Solely dedicated to Islamic period, the objects are well displayed. They are chronologically arranged in the gallery towards right. The gallery towards left has objects displayed as per various themes. I was surprised to find items from India (emperor Akbar's time) here. This is a very quiet, clean, not crowded and well maintained museum. Definitely recommend visiting. P. S - need to buy separate ticket for photography even if clicking pictures with phone camera

Very interesting and there were not so many visitors.. There is quite a bit of stuff exhibited there. Nice divisions into the periods. Very interesting weaponry area. Worthy to visit. Photos for extra charge

A great alternative to the outdoor cafes nearby.  You can comfortably sit in a clean setting and enjoy some pretty good food.  Although it can get a bit noisy when a large group comes through.  But the food is worth it.

Absolutely incredibly personable employees running an old school cafe like no other. It’s my favorite spot nestled high atop the old city, providing breathtaking views to go along with your delicious food!
An excellent buffet restaurant in the Jewish Quarter.  We ate there twice in 5 days.  The staff welcomed us very warmly.  A good view of the Temple Mount and Mount of Olives.
Very good place to have a lunch with perfect view
Had a post bar mitzvah at the Kotel breakfast there with family. Tatsy fresh food, very attentive staff. Kosher

Generally speaking it is a nice deli and coffee house. They good selection of cheeses and make nice sandwiches from the baguettes of Russel's bakery. The coffee is good quality as well.
The only thing is that I don't suggest you to count on eating on Friday after 13:00, although they close only at 14:30, the kitchen closes much earlier.
It is dairy kosher and children and baby friendly.
Place was full when we got there so they made us a very generous cheese platter to go, we sat at a near by park and it was absolutely magical!!
Such a homey, welcoming and cozy place! Always fresh and excelent food!! Absolutely our favorite place in Jerusalem.
Glorious place to find hidden cheese

One of my favourite places in jerusalem! 
A charming boutique fromagerie with an excellent cheese selection. 
Highly recommended!

If your looking for fast food - in the heart of the Jewish quarter of the old city of Jerusalem you may want to check this place out. Their Burgers are considered their prime product on their menu. Just keep in mind that this place at some hours of the day gets very busy. Oh - it's a Kosher shop so don't try to order a cheeseburger here!

this place is so delicious!!! i came here with a few friends and i tried the burgers and it was like heaven!!! the best burgers ever tasted, you make baltimore look like a trash dump(oh wait it already is) i will definitely be back here when i make my trip to israel again
Great lamb burgers, great service!
Good for a quick bite

Burgers bar is a nice place for a family to eat. There are high chairs family booths and the service is good. The staff cooks the food well and the place is very popular. Most days there is a 5-10 minute wait for your meal. The prices are very reasonable as well. I recomend eating at Burgers Bar in the Old City of Jerusalem in The Jewish Quarter.
Dobre zaopatrzenie i rozsądne ceny

Found this place in passing. They take credit card so I ate here. Lovely interior and great menu with signature dishes.  My server was really friendly and helpful.  I ordered the signature fish dish and it was really good. Also had the mint iced tea which was great.  I'm glad I didn't go to one of the more touristy places with mediocre looking food.  Prices here are reasonable. Very happy that I ate here on my last day. The meal and experience was memorable.
Tasty food, good atmosphere and friendly service. Much nicer than most of the other restaurants in the old city. Highly recommend.

We came a big group. 
About the service, is was wonderful! Kindful and snap.. 
The food was good but no more than that.

We had a wonderful time, the food was really good, the home made iced tea amazing. The waiters were so nice and very welcoming. I rencommre it a lot !!! And not too touristic !! 
Thanks !
Wonderful food. We had dinner down in the lower level.  Couches and stools with a Mediterranean flair.  Would definitely bring friends and family.
Top
Food authentic #Jerusalem

Super restaurant très accueillant dans une petite rue à peine visible. Il y a une terrasse donnant sur une petite cours a l entrée très typique. Les serveurs sont très sympas et serviables. La bière est servie dans des verres glacés à l avance. Je conseille le jus de grenade pressé sur place, délicieux. Le burger de bœuf Angus est super bon et copieux. Le plus, c est le prix c est vraiment pas cher. Enfin les toilettes sont très propres. Je conseille les yeux fermés.
Abbiamo trovato questo ristorante grazie all'indicazione della nostra guida e siamo rimasti molto soddisfatti della scelta! Molto buono il cibo e buono anche il servizio, consigliato!
Very expensive. Good food. Minimum tourist pride is 25 shekel per person, no matter how much you order.
Traditional Arabic food. This is the place to be. Amazing meat meals or vegetarian. You will enjoy Well cooked food with traditional indoor surroundings.
Best hummus in town and very friendly, truly local atmosphere.
The best hummus in the world. Organic and traditional. The musabah is also great
Good food, but the venue has no comfort at all.

Side salads and hummus were good, lamb kebap not very hot anymore. I think it already stood arround some minutes  before seving. Definitly not on direct way  from Grill to us....
The Olive Pol on the hummus was not tasty! It would have been better without.

Incredible food, we got the tabouleh and Turkish salad to start, and were also given two complimentary dishes. For the main we had the veal kebab and chicken shashlick- full of authentic flavour and spices. 

I can't rave about this enough about this place, if you want a break from hummus and pita, this is it. 

Service was also wonderful, Al Nasr is great!

*edit: food was so good we went back the next day, and had another delightful meal as well as a lovely conversation with one of the men who works there. Amazing food, atmosphere was so inviting, and it's open on Shabbat!
Cold falafel and chicken pita was left somewhere for 10 minutes
Low price and nice quality arabic restaraunt. Tasty meal, fresh juices. My guests enjoyed it very much.
Sehr gutes Restaurant mit grosszügigen Portionen, freundlicher Bedienung und sehr preiswert, mitten in der Altstadt. Absolut zu empfehlen!

It's nice seeing people from different religions and confessions praying together the One God in one place. In contrast to the Holy city of Jerusalem where finding a place to meditate is so hard, the Western Wall allows the believer to pass a quiet time of reflection and prayer

The energy, architecture, and peacefulness that was felt when I visited the Western Wall was absolutely amazing. There were a lot of people who visited, but it didn't seem to get overly crowded, which was nice.
Beautiful and Holy place. I am very thankful to the Jewish people for sharing this and allowing the world to share in what is most sacred to them.

As a person who doesn't pray whatsoever, nor am I religious in any other way, I still enjoyed the peacefulness and energy of the place. If not for religious reasons, go for the beautiful structures and vibes of Jerusalem

No word can describe my feeling when see this magnificent wall. For those who like me who are not believing in the religion, this is a very worthy place to visit and feel the culture with the Jewish people.

Lovely place in the heart of the City. Very interesting and some rare plant collections. Especially, I want to outline orangeries and Bonsais collection. Pretty cozy restaurant you can find there after tour view.

Very nice place. Beautiful well held, enjoyed it took the kids and we had fun really worth the visit, I will do it again. 👍 If you have a student or a Yershalmi card you'll get a discount and the kids entrance will be free. 😁
A great place for botany lover. Variety of plants, organized in a very nice way.
Nice for short trip, very peaceful and quiet. There are not many benches there so take that on account

Nice place, fun play area for the kids. I really liked the bonsai trees-they have quite a collection. I had a really fun day there with my family. 
The entrance of the place is really difficult to find, and people on the street had no clue where the entrance is. They also didn't have a first aid kit or even band-aids available. I cut the palm of my hand on broken, rusted metal- the banister of the stairscase in the parking lot, and there was nothing (but water) to clean it out with. They also blamed me for getting cut. They said I shouldn't have touched their broken banister!

Great entrance into the Old City from Jaffa Street past Jerusalem City Hall, past Mamilla Mall, Aroma Coffee, into the Jaffa Gate, Rampart Walkways, Clean Public Restrooms, Tower of David, Armenian Quarters, Jewish Quarters. And sometimes some entertainment! See pics
Great gathering point, biggest square piazza in Jerusalem center. Nice benches to sit on, right next to light train jaffa center station.
Beautiful place to just sit for a while. Lots of nice seating.
A beautiful place with cafes, restaurants and fast food restaurants. I recommend to visit in the evening.
Go there to get a good feel of this amazing city

Still providing accommodation but not exactly an affordable youth hostel, now a hotel. Gym and swimming pool. Good place to stay or visit to get a feel of how things changed in Jerusalem over time.  Elaborate Christmas decorations most of December and through Hanukkah celebrations.
A place full of rich history.  Excellent location.  With the access to a first class gym.  Definitely should visit.

Polite and wonderful staff, this place needs a major renovation of the existing rooms.  Understand from staff that a floor will be opening up late next month from renovation.  Good location though about a 10 min walk to the Jaffa gate of the old city.

This is a very nice gym,  but RIDICULOUSLY expensive. Everything here is good, but not great. The basketball gym is good, but the floor could be better. The weightlifting gym is also good, but doesn't have an excess of machines or benches. All in all, everything here is just good, which is not what you would want if you were paying 300 shekel a month for a gym. You could get something better in America for 30$ a month, but, since you're in Israel, if you really want a gym or basketball court or pool, you may have to pay the exorbitant price for it.
Enjoyed lunch with friends. The lobby was spectacularly dressed for Christmas and this created a special ambience. Friendly and professional service.
Very interesting small museum. Excellent tour by knowledgeable english speaking guide.
Beautiful synagogue 300 years old from Carneggio Jewish community. Open for Sabbath prayers.
A small museum, focused on juwish history, very interesting and informative. There are a lot of explainsions near the exhibits and an active synagogue in the building.
Authentic old, small synagogue brought to Israel from Italy, beautifully restored. Hood, knowledgeable guide. Call to arrange in advance.
Small museum. Beautiful restored synagogue and a few rooms of Judaica.  More cost effective to go to Israel museum.
This place is simple and awesome. As in filled with awe.

Won't address what I think about the institution but will talk only about the building, which is absolutely AMAZING. One of the most beautiful architectures in the city and in Israel, with a lot of natural light and a lot of symbols and meaning in how it was built. A gift for any photographer of architecture lover, views on the city and beautiful garden nearby as a bonus (also, worth checking the building from the outside and don't miss the courtyard!).
Free daily tours that are open to the general public take place at 11 a.m. in Hebrew and at 12 noon in English.
Accessibility: accessible parking, entrance to the building, toilets, water stations, voice guidance system, audio assistance system at the reception, directing signage, audio systems in courtrooms.
I believe everyone in Israel's supreme court should watch Lauren Southern's video on why feminism is an antynom for equality. Feminism is a movement for entitlements and supremacy.
They got a illuminati thing on top that aint cool. Flip the (bad) jews in here
Very impressive. Highly recommend the guided tour is about 1 hour long. Free.

One of the most interesting museums I’ve been in my life. Audio tour is great but a personal tour is the best.
During “tour rush hour” it gets very crowded.

An amazing place with incredible stories, pictures, videos and more. Really heart felt.
Just amazing

Such a moving and sobering experience!  This brings the holocaust to life in a way I hadn’t experienced before.  My heart hurt for the past, but I left with hope for the future.  The Children’s memorial was so sad yet amazing and special!

On my recent trip to Israel, I visited Yad Vashem for the first time in several years.  It has certainly changed.  The museum is much larger, including space for special exhibits.  I am certainly glad I send them a yearly donation  It's money well spent.

That is a breathtaking place. A must visit. Only seeing all the items, pictures and videos you realize once again the tragedy of the Holocaust. The garden of the righteous is also amazing. So many people risked their lives for helping Jewish people .

Wow! !   Such history.  When the dead sea scroll on the book of Isiah was found it was being torn and sold as the young man needed the money.  So when it was discovered that this was happening it was stopped and recovered. it is now on display and unrolled for all to enjoy,  plus many other artifacts. I spent so much time just enjoying all that had been discovered. 🌹
Display of Dead Sea Scrolls was done artfully and beautifully. Great history descriptions scattered throughout museum that answered all questions. Enjoyed the tour.

Historically significant and informative exhibit, however we were disappointed by how few pages of the actual scrolls were on display. We were expecting reams but only saw a few pages. So just manage your expectations. The rest of the museum is very impressive so altogether it's worth a visit.

It houses some incredible testimonials from Jewish history and origin. The scrolls found in this shrine cannot be found anywhere else in the world.
The presentation is very impressive, and although it hasn't changed in a while you can always find new and exciting ways to look at it.
Unfortunately it isn't really wheelchair accessible.

This is a place to prove that the Death sea scroll is one of a strong evidence, that Bible from 3000 years ago is not corrupt. And what was writen on it, accurately the same as the Bible people buy from the book store.  As  a christian its an encouragement for you to go and see with your bearly eyes, how does God work on Earth.
Great museum with very interesting collection. I especially liked the Persian, ottoman and Mughal collections. The modern art was so-so. The clock collection is exceptional!

Amazing collection limited by its presentation.

This museum is really 2 collections in one: (Eastern) Islamic art, and an unrelated clock collection in the basement. Each includes many amazing pieces. But many pieces are marked removed, with no date on which they're expected to return. And I suspect many more precedent presented.
The clock collection also suffers from being in poor working order, with some of the most intriguing mechanisms not activated, or activated but incorrectly set! The latter is especially jarring in a field where precision is the name of the game.

Also there seem to be no new or loaned items. A shame for such a lovely collection, on such a gem of a building!

A wonderful museum, with a great permanent collection and also rotating exhibitions. The building it self is beautiful and the atmosphere and orientation are just right. Great for adults and kids. Parking in the area can sometimes be problematic but bus number 13 has a stop next by. There is also an elderly care house next door planned by the same architect, which  is also quite nice.
Excellent and interesting museum. Highly recommended.
Excellent museum, beautifully laid out. Clock room is a must!!

Worth seeing place, excellent to visit with kids, interesting and reach exhibitions, many kinds of different species of animals displayed, but also prehistoric part with interesting fossils and reconstructions of dinos, geological part with different minerals and gems and ethnographic exhibition. My son was just amazed and not bored at all - there were several kids corners to draw but what was the most exciting to him - there were exhibits that he could touch or play with!
You just dont know how large the exibition is when you arrive at the front door. Very well elaborated, easy to move inside the building. I loved.
It was nice and interesting but no explanations in English
A wonderful museum, especially for kids. You get to see and touch all kinds of animals. A must see of you are at Bergamo!
So many dinosaurs! Fun place in old town Bergamo.

Very interesting and well done.  A different kind of museum.   Tells story of Begin in several videos.   The only way to see museum is with a guide. All videos are in Hebrew,  but headphones have other languages.   English was easy to understand.   Highly recommended.

you get a front an up-close look into the insight and making of a leader from per-holocaust Europe Jewry and into a modern 2000 century era Israel leader, stepping foot into his life and sitting in his living room, gives us a bit of an understanding about Jewish pride and country..
This is an outstanding Museum in memory to Menachem Begin. We really enjoyed the audio visual tour and the exhibits.
Terrific.  We had a tour and talk with Dr. Gabi Barkay.
A nice space, easy to get to and clean bathrooms.

The house of Agnon is a recommended attraction to anyone who's interested in Shai Agnon's writing or literature as a whole. If you aren't really in to that kind of thing, don't go there, it's not worth it.
The home is well preserved but also relatively small. A tour can be completed in one hour. The library upstairs is special.
Nice afternoon in Agnon house. Only me during the stay. A quite place for me to think the life.
Quiet place interesting fact about the owner
It was a n interesting tour of the house where the famous Noble prize winner lived and worked.

Loved this museum! Very interactive and educational. Kids would also love this place. The staff are super friendly and very kind even after I accidental spilled water from my bag on the floor. Sorry for that. Had heaps of fun here!

Musical instruments, stories and explanations, following the diverse music and instruments all over the Jewish world from the Temple times to now. Fascinating. Don't miss the Temple 360 experience at the end of your tour, you are transported to a different time and era. Thrilling! We took the guided tour (you have to book in advance,no extra charge), recommended. Otherwise, there are tablets with earphones, all included in admission price of the museum. They say you need an hour, I could have happily stayed two + hours and if you are an OCD musician, think three to four hours!

Good place for rambunctious kids. Annoying for serious adult music lovers. Tour guides have their charges blowing loud instruments as you try to listen to recorded descriptions. They also claim right-of-way while you try to study an exhibit. Nifty virtual reality tour of the ancient Temple worth 'seeing' although unrelated to music.
Beautiful place. Very interesting. Great food venues and lively atmosphere in the plaza...
Interesting idea but too much to read. No place to sit for elderly or other physically challenged people.

Nice place to come! There are fountains with music in the evening. Upstairs you can find the world sculpture (popular place for photos). If you go other way of the entrance along the park you will reach a beautiful area where used to live (maybe and lives now) creative elite. It will be on your right hand. And after you will see an old mill with fantastic viewpoint.

Fun for summer afternoon. Not a lot of shade. The splash pad is only activated for about 25 minutes every hour and a half! Not very much at all! If you time it right, it can work out nicely, but no guarantees.
We've been here at a winter event , not many people and not that much to do . But it was nice and we had a good time
Cool place to take kids in the summer. Right by the old city. The fountains is awesome, but it does get a bit crowded. Check the Times bc it only goes off about 4-5 times a day.
Very nice place to lie down and just chill.

Very nice outside space indeed. Not much specific attractions (which is totally fine with me), I had a great time there with my kids and my dad playing ball and freesbie. There's a restaurant there these days, haven't bee inside. Supposedly there's a public bathroom as well

Great park lots of basketball courts if you need a 3×3 this is the place to get the energy out on a quick game great paid parking or nearby free parking up to you and the greenery and water fountains all working enjoy this place every time
Awesome courts and areas to chill. Well kept clean facilities. Very often pick up games that you can split into.

There is so much to do at Liberty Bell Park! Well lit for evening use!!
Easy to walk to from many locations! Plenty of Basketball courts, equipment for exercising, a beautiful skateboard park and a soccer field! Lots of fun places for children to explore with their parents!! Wow Jerusalem, I am impressed!

A "green lung" in the middle of Jerusalem southern suburbs.
Wonderful to walk through or simply to relax.
The vegetation mutes the sound of the busy street which runs along the east side of the park.
Nice place to visit with the kids - swings. slides et al with a sunshade covering.
Lots of places to eat, shop and chill out over the road at "The Tachana" [New Train Station] -check it out too.
Enjoy enjoy

Невелика синагога «Бейт-Тфіла Біньямін» була збудована 1923 року на пожертвування родини Біньяміна Шапіро. 1938 року на будинку було встановлено меморіальну дошку з написом, виконаним єврейськими літерами німецькою мовою (не їдишем). Це свідчить про те, наскільки чернівецькі євреї були асимільовані в німецькомовну культуру навіть у період румунського правління, яке чинило опір німецькому культурному впливу. В період з 1959 по 1994 рр. вона була єдиною діючою синагогою в місті. Особливу цінність становлять її внутрішні розписи, виконані невідомим чернівецьким художником. Розписи вкривають практично весь внутрішній простір приміщення. За своєю самобутністю та художнім рівнем ці розписи є визначним зразком релігійної єврейської творчості Східної Європи.
בית כנסת
Дом Родной!!!
Delicious falafel! Very fresh! Kind staff!
Great food and good price :)
Best falafel
Good, real falafel!
Great Falafel!

American style spacious resturant, nice environment. The hamburger is delicious 😋, the menu is versatile, different toppings are available. The prices are reasonable.
Recommended.

our first night in Jerusalem on a Friday (shabbos) we settled for burgers. No problems as the meal was tasty and reasonably priced. The medium sized burger was tasty and satisfying along with the fries. The lamb burger according to my mate was also flavorful and the onion rings just right. There was also an Irish Pub around the corner which we will check out the next time.
Great meat. Good food, fast service, a little pricy but that's how it is on all places that are not old city /east Jerusalem.
This is the best place to eat in the land of , vegetables, falafel and shawarma. Good awesome tasty meat. Just the way I like it!!! Yum
The hamburger and service are good. Wasnt a Fan of the home sauce. Over all a good place for a night meal.

I've eaten here multiple times and love the restaurant. The food is the best Italian food that I have found in Jerusalem and is on par with some of the best Manhattan Italian restaurants. The owner is originally from Milan and sings opera on the side, entertaining the guests and is the most wonderful host! The service is quick and professional. Do try the banana caramel crepe if you go!
Best place! Great Italian food, extremely nice service, authentic and charming owner who'd beautifully sing you if you'd ask. Highly recommend. Advise: order table in advance
Nice quiet place. Authentic Italian cuisine. Reasonable prices. Appropriate for children. Don't forget the desserts!!

Delicious fresh food! Excellent service! The owner/chef was so friendly and special making this restaurant a true gem in the heart of Jerusalem. Beautiful location as well and conveniently located on a lightrail stop.
This place receives 3.5 stars for delicious food and quick service. I would love to give it five stars however for 60+ shekels a dish I expect a much bigger serving.

Still providing accommodation but not exactly an affordable youth hostel, now a hotel. Gym and swimming pool. Good place to stay or visit to get a feel of how things changed in Jerusalem over time.  Elaborate Christmas decorations most of December and through Hanukkah celebrations.
A place full of rich history.  Excellent location.  With the access to a first class gym.  Definitely should visit.

Polite and wonderful staff, this place needs a major renovation of the existing rooms.  Understand from staff that a floor will be opening up late next month from renovation.  Good location though about a 10 min walk to the Jaffa gate of the old city.

This is a very nice gym,  but RIDICULOUSLY expensive. Everything here is good, but not great. The basketball gym is good, but the floor could be better. The weightlifting gym is also good, but doesn't have an excess of machines or benches. All in all, everything here is just good, which is not what you would want if you were paying 300 shekel a month for a gym. You could get something better in America for 30$ a month, but, since you're in Israel, if you really want a gym or basketball court or pool, you may have to pay the exorbitant price for it.
Enjoyed lunch with friends. The lobby was spectacularly dressed for Christmas and this created a special ambience. Friendly and professional service.
